    The Rise of Molecules Able To Regenerate the Central Nervous System

    • Vinícius Barros Ribeiro da Silva*
      Vinícius Barros Ribeiro da Silva
      Université Grenoble Alpes, Département de Chimie Moléculaire, UMR 5250, CNRS, F-38041 Grenoble, France
      *E-mail: [email protected]
      More by Vinícius Barros Ribeiro da Silva
      View Biography
      http://orcid.org/0000-0001-9712-6985
      • , 
    • Marimélia Porcionatto
      Marimélia Porcionatto
      Universidade Federal de São Paulo, Escola Paulista de Medicina, Laboratório de Neurobiologia Molecular, Departmento de Bioquímica, Rua Pedro de Toledo, 669 - third floor, 04039-032 São Paulo, São Paolo, Brazil
      More by Marimélia Porcionatto
      View Biography
      • , and 
    • Vinicius Toledo Ribas
      Vinicius Toledo Ribas
      Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais, Instituto de Ciências Biológicas, Departamento de Morfologia, Laboratório de Neurobiologia Av. Antônio Carlos, 6627, room O3-245, - Campus Pampulha, 31270-901, Belo Horizonte, Minas Gerais, Brazil
      More by Vinicius Toledo Ribas
      View Biography
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2020, 63, 2, 490–511

    SUBJECTS:

    • Optics
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Injury to the adult central nervous system (CNS) usually leads to permanent deficits of cognitive, sensory, and/or motor functions. The failure of axonal regeneration in the damaged CNS limits functional recovery. The lack of information concerning the biological mechanism of axonal regeneration and its complexity has delayed the process of drug discovery for many years compared to other drug classes. Starting in the early 2000s, the ability of many molecules to stimulate axonal regrowth was evaluated through automated screening techniques; many hits and some new mechanisms involved in axonal regeneration were identified. In this Perspective, we discuss the rise of the CNS regenerative drugs, the main biological techniques used to test these drug candidates, some of the most important screens performed so far, and the main challenges following the identification of a drug that is able to induce axonal regeneration in vivo.

    Part 1: Literature Review. I. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Injuries to the mature central nervous system (CNS), including traumatic brain and spinal cord injury, often leave devastating sensory, permanent motor, and/or cognitive deficits in patients. Most of these conditions involve axon damage, which in turn induces axonal degeneration and, in some circumstances, neuronal death, leading to neurological deficits. Although some neurons can survive an axonal injury, in the adult mammalian CNS they fail to regrow and reconnect their axons. Together, neurodegeneration and the failure of axon regeneration result in the loss of function of affected neuronal populations and cannot be repaired by any available therapy. In principle, functional recovery after CNS damage requires the reestablishment of the neuronal circuitry lost as a consequence of axonal injury and the resulting secondary damage. Thus, the promotion of robust axon regeneration may lead to novel treatments for a variety of neurological disorders.
    Regardless of the regenerative inability of mature mammalian CNS neurons, various animals, including invertebrates, fish, amphibians, and reptiles, can spontaneously regenerate their axons.(1) Moreover, neurons from the mammalian peripheral nervous system (PNS) are able to promote functional axon regeneration.(2) Unlike adult CNS neurons, developing CNS neurons can also regenerate their axons after injury.(3) Based on these differences in axon regeneration abilities, it has been proposed that mammalian CNS neurons lose the ability to regrow axons during development. Over the past few decades, much research using different animal models has been aimed at the cellular and molecular mechanisms of axon regeneration. Today, it is well-known that the inability of axonal regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS is due to an imbalance between two main factors: “intrinsic”, related to the loss of axon regrowth capacity, and “extrinsic”, related to the inhibitory environment.(4)
    Despite significant progress in promoting CNS regeneration in experimental animal models, even with the most promising pro-regenerative strategies, functional recovery is still limited or absent, and the regenerative response evoked by those strategies is incomplete in terms of both the distance traveled by regenerating axons and the fraction of neurons that respond to treatment. Together, these findings highlight the critical need for additional strategies to promote robust axon regeneration in the CNS.
    Here, we will first summarize the experimental injury models used to study axon regeneration, present evidence showing the role of extrinsic and intrinsic mechanisms controlling axon regrowth, and then focus on current progress in the discovery of drugs that are able to promote CNS regeneration, which were discovered through high-throughput screening techniques. Finally, we will discuss the possible effects triggered upon regenerative strategies to promote CNS repair.

    2. Experimental Models to Study Axon Regeneration

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The molecular mechanisms involved in axon regeneration, as well as drugs that interfere with the regenerative process, have been studied using several in vivo and in vitro models. The most common in vitro protocols use primary cultures of neonatal mice or rat cerebellar granule neurons (CGNs), neurons from the dorsal root ganglia (DRG) of rodents or chicken embryos, and hippocampal or cortical neurons isolated from rodent embryos.(5) Cell lineages such as NG108-15, Neuro2a, and PC12, derived from rat and mouse glioma, neuroblastoma, and pheochromocytoma, respectively, are also used for axonal outgrowth in in vitro assays.(5−7)
    The approach to investigate axonal/neurite outgrowth as a measurement of regeneration is based on the culture of primary or lineage neural cells on a substrate that is permissive to neurite extension (Figure 1). Neurite outgrowth could be visualized in living cells (by fluorescent proteins) or fixed cells (by different staining methods) and measured either manually, using open source image processing programs such as ImageJ, from the NIH, or automatically using dedicated programs or applications.(8,9) For a recent review about the in vitro models of axonal regeneration see Al-Ali et al.(10)
    In vitro studies using compartmentalized chambers have greatly improved the understanding of axonal biology. One interesting device was described by Taylor et al., which consists of a microfluidic chamber that separates axons from soma and dendrites.(11) This model allows the analysis of axon de- and regeneration after axotomy in vitro in real-time by live imaging. Also, this device can isolate the fluid of axonal and soma/dendrite compartments, allowing the influence of various drugs on those cellular compartments to be directly tested. Moreover, it is possible to analyze the expression of proteins and RNAs specifically in axons. Therefore, this platform is a useful and reproducible method to test the role of different compounds in axon regeneration after axonal injury.
    In vivo assays to study axon regeneration in mammals include optic nerve, spinal cord, and sciatic nerve injuries.(12−19) One of the most widely used experimental models to study axon regeneration in the CNS is the optic nerve injury model. Among the advantages of this model, we can include the fact that the optic nerve contains axons only from one easily accessed cell type, retinal ganglion cells (RGCs), and has a clinical functional relevance. Moreover, the administration of molecules to RGCs is relatively easy by intravitreal injection. Axon regrowth in the optic nerve can be evaluated by different techniques (e.g., anterograde axonal tracing with cholera toxin subunit B (CTB) or by immunostaining with GAP43).(20,21) In addition, axon regeneration can be visualized three-dimensionally in cleared whole-mounted optic nerves by confocal microscope reconstruction.(22) This setup allows axons to be scanned throughout the entire thickness of the optic nerve. Single axons in the rat optic nerve can also be imaged by in vivo time-lapse after axonal labeling with adeno-associated viral vector (AAV)-mediated expression of fluorescent reporter proteins (e.g., GFP, dsRed, or mCherry).(23) Although this protocol was originally described to monitor axonal degeneration, it could also be used to test for drugs that interfere with early axonal regrowth. Due to these advantages, the optic nerve is frequently used to investigate the roles of specific molecules in axon regeneration in the CNS. The main effects of gene manipulation and intravitreal virus/drug injections on axonal regeneration can be observed in Figure 2.
    Spinal cord injury is another widely used model to study the mechanisms involved in axon regeneration in the CNS. Injury types range from complete or partial transection to the contusion model. Usually, the main focus is the regeneration of dorsal corticospinal tract axons, and also the rubrospinal tract located in the lateral funiculus, both of which are involved in motor function.(26,27) Strategies to promote the regeneration of those axons include the manipulation of extrinsic factors, by the local application of drugs, molecules, or cell transplants, and/or the modulation of intrinsic mechanisms by gene transfer approaches or drugs.(28) Axon regrowth is usually visualized by axonal tracing, using an anterograde tracer (e.g., biotin dextran amine) or the virus-mediated expression of fluorescent reporter genes (e.g., GFP, dsRed, or mCherry).(29,30) Importantly, spinal cord injury is an important clinically relevant condition in humans because it often results in permanent sensory and/or motor deficits,(31) and cannot be sufficiently repaired by any existing therapy. Therefore, spinal cord lesions provide a clinically relevant model with which to test the effectiveness of different drugs to promote regeneration in the CNS.

    3. Extrinsic Targets Involved in Axon Regeneration

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    For more than 25 years, astrocytes and oligodendrocytes have been recognized as producers of molecules that inhibit neurite sprouting and axonal outgrowth after injury to the adult mammalian CNS.(32−34) The four molecules myelin-associated glycoprotein (MAG), NogoA, oligodendrocyte myelin glycoprotein (OMGp), and chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans (CSPGs) have been identified as the main inhibitors present at the glial scar, and the molecular mechanisms underlying the action of each of these molecules, alone or in combination, have been revealed more recently.
    Around the injury site, astrocytes become reactive, and increase the expression of several genes, including glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP),(35) which is used as a marker for astrocyte activation, together with galectin-3.(36) Astrocyte activation, or astrogliosis, is an early response to CNS injury and is responsible for forming the glial scar that will prevent the lesion from spreading the inflammatory response.(37)
    MAG, a transmembrane protein and member of the family of sialic acid-binding proteins (Siglec), is produced by oligodendrocytes.(34,38,39) NogoA was initially described as having neurite growth inhibitory activity,(40,41) and identified as a member of the Reticulon family almost 10 years later.(42−44) OMgp is a GPI-anchored glycoprotein expressed by astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and neurons, and is a component of CNS myelin.(45−47) Finally, the fourth class of molecules involved in neurite/axonal outgrowth inhibition are the CSPGs, a class of proteoglycans that is abundant in the CNS.(48,49) In the normal, uninjured brain, the main CSPGs found are RPTP-beta, phosphacan, NG2, brevican, aggrecan, and neurocan. Some of them, e.g., RPTP-beta and brevican, are transmembrane proteoglycans, while others, such as phosphacan, are secreted and deposited in the extracellular matrix by oligodendrocytes, astrocytes, and neurons, and are overexpressed after CNS injury.(50,51) CSPGs have also been associated with the presence of reactive astrocytes in neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer’s disease.(52,53)
    Since the discovery of inhibitory molecules, several groups have attempted to use them as targets for treatments that would restore neurite sprouting, axonal outgrowth, and synapse formation, culminating in CNS regeneration. CSPG and Nogo are the most well studied targets for interventions, but with no success to date (for a recent review, see Tran et al. 2018).(54) Several groups tested the use of chondrotinases AC and ABC to degrade chondroitin sulfate (CS), the glycosaminoglycan portion of CSPG. In vitro studies using dissociated embryonic chick dorsal root ganglionic neurons grown on normal and injured adult spinal cord tissue sections(55) or organotypic cocultures of the rat brain cortex and spinal cord(56) showed increased neurite and axon length when cells were treated with chondroitinase ABC. Bone marrow-derived mononuclear cells were used to deliver chondroitinase AC to a traumatic brain injury site in the cortex of mice, showing the increased degradation of CSPGs.(57) Similarly, the delivery of thermostabilized chondroitinase ABC was demonstrated to enhance functional recovery and axonal outgrowth following spinal cord injury.(15)
    Recently, a loss of function genome-wide in vitro search for axonal outgrowth inhibition genes identified more than 500 regeneration phenotypes among 16,007 individually knocked-down genes.(58) Rab GTPases, a class of transport-regulating proteins, were identified in the screen, and Rab27b was validated as an inhibitor of axonal regeneration.
    The prevalent knowledge states that glial scar components are the main reason for neurite sprouting and axonal outgrowth inhibition, but recent studies argue against this idea. First, Anderson and colleagues showed that if glial scar formation is prevented or attenuated, no spontaneous axonal growth occurs.(59) The second piece of data that argues against glial scar inhibition of axonal regrowth is based on the mechanical properties of the normal brain tissue and glial scar tissue. Moeendarbary and colleagues described injured rat cortex and spinal cord scars as being softer than the normal, uninjured tissue.(60) The authors suggest that the decrease in elastic stiffness is due to the up-regulation of intermediate filaments GFAP and vimentin by astrocytes, as well as some extracellular matrix glycoproteins such as laminin and collagen IV. The role of reactive astrocytes in scar formation was reaffirmed by conditional ablation in a spinal cord injury model in mice using a lentivirus-mediated herpes simplex thymidine kinase/ganciclovir (HSVtk/GCV) system under the regulation of the GFAP promoter.(16) When astrocytes were activated by injury, the expression of GFAP induced suicidal gene expression, leading to astrocyte death. The consequences of the absence of reactive astrocytes at the injury site were defective scar formation, increased spreading of the inflammatory response, and increased neuronal death and neurodegeneration. In combination, these recent papers reinforce the importance of glial scar formation to restrain CNS secondary degeneration following injury.
    Ion influx, such as Ca2+ and Zn2+, also plays a role in axon homeostasis. In the optic nerve, intra-axonal Ca2+ influx, mediated by Ca2+ channels, occurs immediately after crush lesions.(12) Blockage of L-/N-type and T-type Ca2+ channels and the AMPA receptor was able to block Ca2+ influx and almost completely protect the axons from acute axonal degeneration after optic nerve crush.(12) In a follow-up of this study, we showed that, in addition to the effect on blocking acute axonal degeneration, the inhibition of Ca2+ influx also enhanced RGC survival and induced axonal regeneration in the injured optic nerve.(21) These effects were accompanied by modulation of the activities of the calpain, c-Jun N-terminal kinase, and Akt signaling pathways.(21) Despite Ca2+ influx being a very early event after axon lesion, the delayed inhibition of Ca2+ influx was able to decrease axon degeneration after spinal cord contusion injury.(61) However, whether the delayed blocking of Ca2+ influx is able to promote neuronal survival and axon regrowth remains to be tested. In addition to the role of Ca2+ influx in axon homeostasis, recently, the dysregulation of Zn2+ was also implicated in axon regeneration in the optic nerve. Optic nerve injury leads to the elevation of Zn2+ in amacrine cell processes and the consequent transfer via vesicular release into retinal ganglion cells.(62) Either knockdown of the Zn2+-transporter protein ZnT-3 or Zn2+ chelation promotes RGC survival and axon regeneration after optic nerve injury.(62) Taken together, these results suggest that the regulation of Ca2+ and Zn2+ influx could be an interesting therapeutic approach to promote neuroprotection and regeneration after CNS damage.

    4. Intrinsic Targets and Signaling Pathways Involved in Axon Regeneration

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Besides the extrinsic mechanisms, in the past decade, progress in understanding the role of multiple proteins and signaling transduction pathways that intrinsically regulate axon growth has been made. The identification of those pathways controlling axonal sprouting and outgrowth is a crucial step to understand the mechanisms regulating regeneration, as well as to propose strategies to promote CNS repair. Indeed, several players involved in axon regeneration were identified, and their manipulation, mainly performed by gene targeting, resulted in various degrees of axon regrowth in the CNS.(24)
    In recent years, several studies have indicated that down-regulation of the phosphatase and tensin homologue (PTEN) protein results in axon regeneration in the CNS. PTEN antagonizes the action of PI3K, leading to the inactivation of Akt (also termed protein kinase B), which is responsible for activating the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR).(63) Therefore, PTEN inhibition leads to Akt activation and consequently induces mTOR activity.(64,65) The activation of mTOR promotes protein synthesis and also inhibits catabolism by blocking autophagy.(66) In developing neurons, PTEN down-regulation induces axonal outgrowth.(67) In mature neurons, a pioneering study showed that PTEN deletion remarkably enhances axon regeneration following an optic nerve lesion.(20) Moreover, the application of rapamycin, an inhibitor of mTOR, decreased axon regeneration induced by PTEN depletion, indicating a mTOR pathway dependency.(20) Subsequently, a study by the same group showed that PTEN deletion also induces robust axon regeneration in the injured spinal cord.(29) Several other independent studies confirmed these findings, suggesting that PTEN in a central player controlling axon regeneration.(29,68−70) Protein synthesis induced by the mTOR pathway could be an important molecular mechanism leading to axon regeneration, by providing building blocks needed for axonal elongation. Moreover, the inhibition of autophagy and consequent catabolism could also be a key step in promoting axon regeneration following PTEN deletion; however, this remains to be tested. Besides the clear evidence that blocking PTEN enhances the regenerative capacities of CNS axons, most of the studies used genetic manipulations, which is an approach that is difficult to translate to the clinics. Therefore, the pharmacological inhibition of PTEN would be a more effective therapy. Indeed, in the PNS, the application of PTEN inhibitor bisperoxovanadium increased the neurite outgrowth of sensory neurons in vitro and promoted axon regrowth after sciatic nerve transection.(18,19) Although bisperoxovanadium can inhibit PTEN function, its effect is not specific, being able to target other enzymes.(71) This suggests that new pharmacological agents to selectively suppress PTEN activity are necessary. In accordance with that, small peptide targeting PTEN was able to stimulate neurite outgrowth in vitro and enhance growth of descending serotonergic fibers after spinal cord injury.(17) These findings implicate the PTEN/mTOR signaling pathway in the control of axonal regrowth and, thus, point to this pathway as a potential target by which to promote axon regeneration in the CNS.
    Another important modulator of axon regeneration is the JAK/STAT3/SOCS3 signaling pathway.(72) Janus kinase (JAK) is activated by the binding of different cytokines to membrane receptors. Activated JAK phosphorylates STATs (signal transducer and activator of transcription), including STAT3, translocate into the nucleus and regulate gene expression.(73) A family of proteins termed suppressor of cytokine signaling (SOCS), which includes SOCS3, is a target of the JAK/STAT3 pathway. SOCS3 inhibits JAK/STAT3, working as a negative feedback loop to limit the intensity and duration of cytokine signaling.(74) One of the early pieces of evidence indicating a role for this pathway in axon regeneration showed that, using rat primary sensory neurons in vitro, STAT3 induction promotes neurite outgrowth, whereas the up-regulation of SOCS3 blocks it.(75) Consistent with these findings, deletion of SOCS3 has been shown to promote robust regeneration of the injured optic nerve axons.(76) Moreover, the overexpression of STAT3 promotes the remodeling of lesioned axons and enhances the sprouting of unlesioned axons after spinal cord injury.(77) While SOCS3 deletion promotes the regeneration of optic nerve axons, the co-deletion of STAT3 reverses this effect, indicating that STAT3 is a key regulator that promotes axon regeneration induced by SOCS3 down-regulation.(78) Interestingly, the simultaneous deletion of SOCS3 and PTEN further increases axon regeneration in the injured optic nerve and spinal cord, suggesting that these two pathways are independent and work synergistically.(78) Together, given that these two pathways play a key role in axon regeneration, the development of therapeutic agents targeting these pathways is expected to contribute to the treatment of CNS injury.
    In addition to STAT3, other transcription factors, including members of the KLF family, SOX11 and c-Myc, can modulate axon regrowth. The family of transcription factor Krüppel-like factors (KLFs) has members that positively and negatively regulate axon growth. Most members of this family, including KLF4 and KLF9, inhibit axon elongation.(79,80) In contrast, other transcription factors, such as KLF6 and KLF7, promote axon regeneration.(81,82) Interestingly, there is cross-talk between KLF family members and STAT3 in the regulation of axon regeneration. Qin and colleagues showed that KLF4 physically interacts with STAT3 and suppresses STAT3-dependent gene expression and axon regeneration.(83) By contrast, there is a functional synergy between KLF6 and STAT3 to promote the expression of genes relevant to axon extension.(81) These observations suggest that the manipulation of KLF and STAT transcription factors could promote axon regrowth in a synergistic fashion.
    Another example of a transcription factor that promotes regeneration in the CNS is SOX11, which is highly expressed in the developing CNS.(84−87) The overexpression of SOX11 promotes compensatory sprouting and axon regeneration after spinal cord injury. Interestingly, however, SOX11 overexpression impaired the normal recovery of forelimb dexterity that occurs after cervical spinal cord injury, suggesting a detrimental effect of SOX11-induced plasticity.(30)
    Additionally, c-Myc is also a pivotal transcription factor controlling axon regeneration. The oncogene transcription factor c-Myc has various roles in cellular function, including the control of cell cycle progression, proliferation, growth, adhesion, differentiation, apoptosis, and metabolism.(88) Recently, it has been shown that the forced expression of c-Myc, either before or after injury, promotes robust axon regeneration in the optic nerve.(89) Further analysis showed that the combination of c-Myc and ciliary neurotrophic factor (CNTF, a cytokine related to survival-promoting treatment) overexpression with PTEN and SOCS3 deletion, promotes the robust regrowth of injured optic nerve axons. However, some axons grew ectopically into the contralateral optic nerve, indicating guidance issues.(89) Although different players controlling axon elongation have been identified, most studies manipulated these targets using genetic approaches. The identification of pharmacological modulators of these molecules may yield better strategies for the promotion of axon regeneration.
    In addition to the signaling pathways and transcription factors described above, direct modulation of the cytoskeleton has also been used to enhance axon elongation after injury to the CNS. The cytoskeleton, including microtubules and actin filaments, is the structural support of growing axons. During development, the tip of growing axons forms a structure called the growth cone, which is necessary for its elongation. The growth cone is rich in actin filaments at the periphery, within the filopodia and lamellipodia, and microtubules at the center all project with their polymerizing end toward the actin-rich region.(90) Although the dynamics of the cytoskeleton at the growth cone is essential for axon regrowth, we still do not understand precisely how different molecules and signaling pathways control the cytoskeleton in growing axons. Improving our understanding of this is important for the development of new therapeutic strategies to enhance axon regeneration. In the past decade, different studies have manipulated cytoskeleton dynamics to promote axon regeneration. Moderate stabilization of microtubules by low doses of the microtubule-stabilizing drug paclitaxel (Taxol, Figure 3.A) leads to the formation of multiple axons in hippocampal neurons in culture.(91) Accordingly, the moderate stabilization of microtubules by either paclitaxel or epothilone B (Figure 3A) or D increases axon regeneration in vivo following the development of a lesion on the spinal cord(92−94) or optic nerve.(95) In addition, to promote axon elongation, paclitaxel and epothilone B and D also interfere with the formation of inhibitory fibrotic scar tissue, thus facilitating regenerating axons across the lesion site.(92−94)
    Besides the use of molecules that directly influence cytoskeleton dynamics, the manipulation of intrinsic signaling pathways that control it represents an additional strategy to enhance axon regrowth. Cytoskeletal dynamics can be controlled by GTPases, including RhoA (Ras homologous member A).(96) RhoA activation is achieved by the activation of inhibitor receptors: NgR1 and PIR-B, receptors for MAG; Nogo, and OMgp which have p75 as a coreceptor; NgR2, which binds to MAG; and NgR1 and NgR3, receptors for CSPGs (for a review, see Fujita and Yamashita, 2014).(97) RhoA activation culminates in the activation of the Rho-associated coiled-coil-containing protein kinase (ROCK) in lesioned axons, which is responsible for propagating signals to the cytoskeleton, resulting in growth cone collapse and axonal retraction.(97) Therefore, modulation of the Rho/ROCK signaling pathway could be a valuable strategy to promote axonal regeneration and repair in the injured CNS. Indeed, the inhibition of ROCK, either by the expression of a dominant negative mutant or using a shRNA against it, enhances axonal sprouting and regeneration after spinal cord injury.(98,99) In the optic nerve, the knockdown of ROCK2 or RhoA significantly stimulates axonal regeneration after a crush lesion.(100,101) In addition to genetic manipulation of the Rho/ROCK pathway, inhibitors of this pathway have been used to evaluate its role in axon regrowth. Treatment with C3 transferase, an enzyme derived from Clostridium botulinum which selectively inhibits RhoA, promotes axon regeneration in an optic nerve injury model.(102) Later, the same group showed that the inhibition of RhoA with C3 transferase or ROCK with Y-27632 stimulates axon regeneration and the recovery of locomotor motor function after spinal cord injury in adult mice.(96) Similarly, ROCK inhibition by Y-27632 enhances the sprouting of corticospinal tract fibers and accelerates locomotor recovery following spinal cord injury in adult rats.(103) In the visual system, the intravitreal injection of Y-27632 significantly increases the regeneration of optic nerve axons.(104) Nevertheless, in the same study, the application of different doses of dimethylfasudil (Figure 3B), another ROCK inhibitor, produced only minor effects on axonal regrowth.(104) In a recent study using a model of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, treatment with Y-27632 improved motor axon regeneration and the (re)innervation of neuromuscular junctions after sciatic nerve crush.(105) The accumulating evidence discussed above suggests that the modulation of cytoskeleton dynamics, either directly or indirectly by targeting signaling pathways, represents a promising strategy to promote regeneration following axon injury in the CNS.
    Recently, the adaptor protein 14-3-3 was also implicated in axon regeneration.(13) 14-3-3 proteins are a family of regulatory adaptor proteins highly expressed in the CNS, which bind to different proteins regulating the subcellular localization, activity, stability, and interactions.(106) The inhibition of 14-3-3 reduced neurite outgrowth in vitro. Conversely, the knockdown of different 14-3-3 isoforms decreased, whereas overexpression enhanced axon regeneration after scratch lesions of cortical neurons in culture.(13) Moreover, the small molecule fusicoccin-A (Figure 3C), which stabilizes 14-3-3 interactions with client proteins, stimulated axon regeneration after optic nerve crush, but did not promote axon regrowth in a spinal cord injury model.(13) These findings, where 14-3-3 was defined as a critical regulator of axon regeneration in the optic nerve, implicate this protein as a possible target to promote CNS repair; however, additional studies are necessary to optimize the targeting of this adaptor protein in order to promote axon regrowth in other CNS injury models.
    Different proteins have their content or activity modulated during CNS development. Moreover, in addition to development-dependent modulation of protein expression and activity, axonal injury can also regulate regeneration-associated proteins. For instance, the activity of mTOR, which is involved in the induction of axon regeneration, shows a development-dependent decline in CNS neurons. Moreover, axonal injury further diminished neuronal mTOR activity.(20,29) Recently, Belin and colleagues used quantitative proteomics from purified intact and axotomized RGCs to show that 62 proteins were modulated when comparing injured RGCs to the uninjured. Among the regulated proteins, they found proteins know to be involved in axon regeneration, including MAPK, JAK, and members of the mTOR pathway. New proteins include the transcription factor c-Myc, which was found to be highly expressed in adult RGC and was down-regulated after injury to the optic nerve.(89) SOX11, another transcription factor, is highly expressed in the embryonic CNS, but is down-regulated as the CNS matures.(86) Neurons able to extend axons after injury can up-regulate SOX11 expression after axon damage; however, adult CNS neurons cannot.(30,87,107,108) Members of the KLF family also have their expression regulated during development. Interestingly, while KLF4 expression is enhanced in RGC after birth, KLF7 is down-regulated during the same developmental period.(80) These finding suggest that both development and injury trigger changes in the expression and/or activity of proteins that can positively or negatively modulate axon regeneration, thus contributing to the failure in intrinsic regenerative ability of adult CNS neurons.
    An overview of the signaling pathways and proteins controlling axon regeneration is presented in Figure 4.

    5. Strategies for Hit Identification: Neurite Outgrowth Screening

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Starting in the early 2000s, with the popularization of the high-throughput screening (HTS) techniques, many molecules were evaluated according to their ability to enhance neurite outgrowth.(109−112) The results of these screens were sometimes important not only in the field of medicinal chemistry but also to understand the mechanisms involved in regeneration.(109,113)

    5.1. Screening against Extrinsic Factors

    The first reported screenings were conducted to identify molecules able to stimulate neurons to overcome the effects of inhibitory factors (especially in MAG models), culminating in regeneration through an “extrinsic” mechanism.(109)

    5.1.1. Size Does Not Matter. Case 1: A Small Database Screen Identifies EGFR Kinase as an Inhibitor to Axon Regeneration

    Not all screens have the goal of drug discovery; this was the case of Koprivica et al. in 2005.(109) Their major goal was to identify signaling pathways involved in the inhibitory activity of CNS myelin through the screening of a small database with 400 known molecules against CGNs in the presence of MAG. Most of the identified compounds were epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) kinase inhibitors, such as Erlotinib (Figure 5A), an EGFR inhibitor approved for the treatment of cancer with 4-phenyl-quinazoline as a scaffold.(109) These results suggest the involvement of EGFR kinase in the inhibitory effects of myelin substrates. To confirm the role of EGFR in neurite outgrowth, the group used two EGFR inhibitors, AG1478 (a competitive inhibitor) and PD168393 (an irreversible inhibitor) (Figure 5A). They observed that the compounds promoted neurite outgrowth by overcoming MAG inhibition from CGNs, DRG neurons, and retinal explant cultures, but had no effect on cultures containing no MAG substrates.(109)
    Using the optic nerve crush injury model, they showed that treated mice had a 9-fold increase in the number of regenerating axons compared with DMSO (control)-treated mice, but no effect was observed on cell survival.(109) The AG1478 effect was weaker than the effect of PD168393, which is probably related to the reversible EGFR inhibition shown by this compound.(109) With their work, they showed the involvement of EGFR as an important protein in the inhibition of axon regeneration after injury and might suggest EGFR inhibitor compounds as an important class of drugs to promote axon regeneration after CNS injury.(109)

    5.1.2. Triazine Compounds. Case 2: Screen to Identify Compounds That Overcome Glial-Mediated Inhibition

    Bixby’s team screened a new trisubstituted triazine-based library containing 400 compounds (synthesized by a building-block approach by Lee et al. in 2009(114) with unknown biological targets) for the ability to increase CGN neurite outgrowth in the presence of MAG.(110) As enhanced cAMP was shown to promote axonal regeneration overcoming MAG inhibition,(115−119) db-cAMP (a membrane permeable and nonhydrolyzable form of the second messenger cAMP) was used as a positive control. Four compounds (A05, C05, F05, and H08, Figure 5B) were shown to increase neurite outgrowth with results similar to db-cAMP. They also observed that the hit compounds were able to overcome CSPG-mediated inhibition, as observed by Sivasankaran et al. with a PKC inhibitor (Gö6976) (Figure 1B).(120) Thus, the identified compounds were able to overcome the two major “extrinsic” inhibitory mechanisms identified so far: myelin debris and the CSPGs found in the glial scar.(110)
    The results found with the CGNs were reproduced using two other CNS populations that are more relevant to CNS injury (embryonic spinal cord neurons and embryonic cortical neurons) to reproduce the same results as those found before.(110) Compound F05 was the most effective when tested to stimulate the growth ability of RGC neurons (P20) in the presence of CSPG substrate.(110)
    They tested compound F05 using a glial scar model,(121) and observed that the addition of compound F05 to cortical neurons cultured on the glial scar model nearly doubled the number of neurons with neurites and increased the total neurite length of DRG neuron growth on the scar model by almost 50%.(110) They showed that F05 treatment in vivo (optic nerve crush injury model) enhanced the average length of the longest regenerating axons by 56% (compared to negative control) and increased the number of regenerating axons at each distance measured.(14)
    Concerning the mechanism of action, they did not observe any activity of the identified compounds on cAMP, cPKC, and EGFR, in contrast to the previous regeneration-based screen of known bioactive compounds,(109,120,122) but they did show that compound F05 affected microtubule (MT) dynamics in cultured cells, including an increase in stable MTs and a smaller increase in dynamic MTs.

    5.1.3. Ignoring Inhibitory Cues. Case 3: Regeneration via a c-AMP-independent Pathway

    In 2010, another work focused on the screening of molecules to overcome the inhibitory effects of glial factors was conducted by Ma et al.(111) Their work was based on previous studies which identified molecules that promote axonal regeneration through the enhancement of cAMP.(115−119) The elevation of neuronal cAMP overcomes MAG inhibition by activating PKA, leading to the phosphorylation of CREB, and the recruitment of the coactivator CBP/p300 to trans-activate a host of genes, including Arginase 1 (Arg1).(123) Thus, they screened a library containing 2000 compounds (among FDA-approved drugs and safe compounds) against immortalized hippocampal cell clones expressing a firefly luciferase Arg1 promoter-reporter (HT22ap (arginase promoter).(111) This initial screen is the particularity of this work, which is not based on the phenotypic screening, like most of the other works in this domain, but rather on a biochemical approach. Of the 2000 compounds, 40 induce luciferase activity by at least 2-fold, similar to the positive control, while 10 increased Arg1 protein levels on native HT22 cells and were considered “true hits”.(111) The isoflavone was the most frequently recurring scaffold on the 10 molecules; however, even the closely related structures did not have similar activities. For example, daidzein induced Arg1 levels, whereas genistein was ineffective (Figure 5C). Additionally, while many flavones increased reporter activity, only methoxyvone (Figure 5C) was positive in the secondary screen.(111) Among all of the compounds, only daidzein was able to enhance neurite outgrowth in the presence of MAG, while methoxyvone promoted modest neurite outgrowth.(111)
    Daidzein was identified as the most effective compound after the screening and its therapeutic potential was investigated. First, they determined that 20 μM is the best concentration of daidzein to overcome MAG inhibition and enhance neurite outgrowth of CGNs.(111) At this concentration, Arg1 protein levels were increased 3-fold, which is similar to the treatment with 2 mM of db-cAMP. They showed that daidzein up-regulates Arg1 protein levels and that arginase activity is necessary for overcoming MAG-mediated inhibition of axonal outgrowth in CGNs.(111) Using DRG neurons and embryonic cortical neurons, they showed that daidzein activity is sensitive to the neuronal cell type.(111)
    They proved that intrathecally administered daidzein is able to stimulate DRG neurons to overcome MAG inhibition(111) in a dose-dependent manner. DRGs removed from the sacrificed animals receiving 40 μM daidzein overcame inhibition by MAG, while the 20 μM dose had no effect. However, the intrathecal route is an inconvenient and dangerous pathway of administration; thus, they proved that the subcutaneous administration of daidzein is effective to promote neurite outgrowth in the presence of MAG in a millimolar range. Using this route, daidzein needs to cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB) to reach the DRGs.(111) Daidzein was able to promote long-distance axon regeneration in the optic nerve crush injury model in rats.(111) The same results were observed when daidzein was subcutaneously administered.(111)
    Regarding the mechanism of action, they proved that daidzein does not act by increasing cAMP levels or activating PKA to induce Arg1 expression(111) and somehow interacts with estrogen receptors, as reported for daidzein,(124) but not in a clear way.(111)
    Taken together, the results validate the strategy of using Arg1 induction as a biological marker to screen for molecules that overcome MAG axonal growth inhibition and identify daidzein as a hit molecule.(111) Daidzein was effective in many types of neuronal cells. When intrathecally administered in vivo, it was biologically active at the concentrations which are effective in vitro. Their results suggest that daidzein is also biologically active when subcutaneously administered, crossing the BBB in vivo, and may be a viable therapeutic agent to promote axonal regeneration following CNS injury.(111)

    5.1.4. Screen to Know Your Targets. Case 4: Protein Prenylation

    Another interesting work is the study from 2016 led by Li et al.(113) They performed a HTS with 50,401 small molecules in a single concentration (10 μM) to investigate their ability to overcome MAG inhibition using mouse embryonic stem cell-derived motor neurons (mES-MNs) and found that only 1.6% of the tested compounds were defined as hits.(113) Interestingly, they did not detect any biological activity for either of the two small molecules known to promote neurite outgrowth: daidzein(111) or erlotinib.(109) Among them, the most potent lead was simvastatin.(113) They also observed that six other statins (cerivastatin, fluvastatin, simvastatin, lovastatin, mevastatin, and pitavastatin) enhanced mES-MN neurite outgrowth on MAG by more than 2-fold (concentrations between 30 nM and 7 mM) compared to the three remaining (pravastatin, rosuvastatin, and atorvastatin), which showed weak activity. This may be explained by the fact that these three statins were designed to be selective for liver cells.(125,126) Among the statins, cerivastatin (Figure 5D) was the most active, completely overcoming MAG inhibition.(113)
    Using cerivastatin, they proved that statins act directly in neurons and not via other cell types present in the culture, and that cerivastatin was also effective when CSPGs were added. This means that statins are acting more broadly on regeneration and not only inhibiting a MAG-specific signaling mechanism.(113)
    They also proved that statins promote neurite outgrowth through the inhibition of hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-coenzyme A (HMG-CoA) reductase (HMGCR), an enzyme involved in a rate-limiting upstream step in cholesterol biosynthesis.(113,127) However, HMGCR inhibition is implicated in the reduction of cholesterol level, and is known to play many important roles in the synapses, which could damage the CNS.(113) Thus, they decided to investigate other molecules involved in the mevalonate pathway that are able to mimic the biological effects of statins on axon growth without affecting cholesterol.(113) They showed that neither coenzyme Q4 or Q10, HDL, or LDL (high and low-density lipoprotein) present a growth inhibition, demonstrating that it is not necessary to block cholesterol or coenzyme Q synthesis to enhance neurite outgrowth. Farnesyl pyrophosphate (FPP), the last common intermediate between cholesterol synthesis and protein prenylation, and geranylgeranyl pyrophosphate (GGPP), a product of the reaction between FPP and GGPP synthase (GGPPS), which is important for protein prenylation, prevent growth enhancement by cerivastatin. These combined results suggest the inhibition of protein prenylation as the principal mode of statin action to promote neurite outgrowth in neurons.(113)
    They proved that the inhibition of protein prenylation pathways can mimic the effect of statins on axonal growth without cholesterol synthesis inhibition by using two incompletely selective inhibitors of two important enzymes from two different prenylation pathways: protein:geranylgeranyl transferase 1 and 2 (PGGT 1 and 2), and protein:farnesyl transferase (PFT).(113) Using two more selective inhibitors, GGTI-2417 (PGGT 1 selective, Figure 5D) and FTI-2153 (FTI selective, Figure 5D), they showed that both pathways are important for neurite outgrowth, even if the inhibition of PFT leads to better activity than the inhibition of PGGT 1.(113)
    Using the optic nerve crush injury model in mice, they showed that cerivastatin or a combination of GGTI-2417 + FTI-2153 GGTI-2417 intravitreally injected immediately after the crush stimulated the axon regeneration compared to the control.(113) The combination of GGTI-2417 and FTI-2153 produced the same results as cerivastatin, but not when used alone, sustaining the hypothesis of a synergic effect of both prenylation pathways.(113)
    They also confirmed that their results are exploitable to human disease models using two systems of human stem cell-derived motor neurons (the “gold-standard” ES-derived motor neurons expressing Hb9:GFP and neurons derived from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) patients, hiPS-MNs).(113) With their work, Li et al.(113) supported the idea that the mevalonate-prenylation pathway represents a target for therapeutic approaches to currently incurable diseases and trauma to the CNS.

    5.1.5. First Grow Your Neurons. Case 5: L-Type Calcium Channel Blockers

    Recently, Huebner and colleagues(128) screened a database containing 960 compounds (small molecules with known bioactivity and drugs currently in clinical use) for its ability to overcome CSPG inhibition through a cortical scrape assay developed by their team.(129,130) The main advantage of this model is that the embryonic or early postnatal cortical neurons are maintained in culture for several weeks (21 days in vitro, DIV) in order to acquire a phenotype that is closer to adult neurons (especially with regard to receptor expression and responsiveness to extrinsic factors) before the scrape and inclusion of CSPGs and/or compounds. The molecules were screened at 10 μM, and the ROCK2 inhibitor Y27632(103,131) was used as a positive control (Figure 5E). Five hits were identified, among them verapamil (Figure 5E), an L-type calcium channel blocker (L-CCB), which significantly stimulates axon growth. No synergistic effect between the five hits was observed when they were tested in all possible two-drug combinations. Antagonists of other calcium channel subtypes (N-, R-, and T-type) were tested, but no axonal growth was observed. However, another L-CCB, which was structurally different from verapamil, was identified as a hit, diltiazem, suggesting the L-type calcium channel as a mediator of axon growth. Verapamil (10 μM) significantly enhanced axon growth compared to the control when combined with the ROCK2 inhibitor Y27632 (25 μM); however, diltiazem and nifedipine (another L-CCB, Figure 5E) presented an effect that was even stronger when tested in the same conditions. Diltiazem (5 μM) with Y27632 (25 μM) significantly enhanced regeneration, 2-fold when compared with the CSPG control. All of these molecules, individually, can stimulate axon regeneration in the presence of CSPG; however, none of them has any effect in the absence of an inhibitory factor.
    Diltiazem was able to enhance DRG axon growth, a mature neuron, up to 2.0-fold in the presence of CSPG (0.7 μM) and enhance axon length of induced human sensory (iSensory) neurons on CSPG by 1.5-fold at 2 μM. An L-type calcium channel agonist, FPL 64176, was tested in DRG neurons, but no effect was detected. Together, their results indicate that the L-CCB molecules can promote axon growth on the CSPG substrate.

    5.2. Screening against Intrinsic Factors

    New theories suggest that overcoming only the inhibition of glial-scars is not enough to promote regeneration;(59,60) thus, screens focused on the “intrinsic” mechanisms of axonal regeneration have emerged. The main difference between these two screening techniques is based on the neurite outgrowth assay. The first screens used neurons in the presence of MAG and CSPGs,(109−111,113) which are known to inhibit neurite outgrowth and axon regeneration, while the screen to identify “intrinsic” stimulatory drugs did not culture neurons in the presence of these factors.(132−135)

    5.2.1. New Scaffolds and New Targets. Case 6: The Rise of Protein Kinases as Pharmacological Targets to CNS Regeneration

    At the beginning of the 2010s, protein kinases were already known to be related to axonal growth and guidance in vitro and in vivo,(136−139) so much so that research groups started to consider them as likely targets for the pharmacological treatment of CNS regeneration. One interesting work in this field was performed by Samara et al.,(112) who screened a database of 100 well characterized molecules by combining high-throughput microfluidics and femtosecond laser microsurgery in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans.(112) The preliminary results showed that many modulators of protein kinase are able to induce axon regeneration. They found that staurosporine (Figure 6A), a nonselective kinase inhibitor with high affinity for PKC,(140) suppresses posterior lateral microtubule (PLM) neuron regeneration, but does not alter the regeneration of other neuron populations from C. elegans.(112) The importance of these results was highlighted after the observation that regeneration is significantly enhanced by the PKC activator prostratin (Figure 6A). Their results were consistent with many in vitro studies on vertebrate organisms at the time,(141−144) wherein the administration of PKC inhibitors following mechanical lesions affects neurite outgrowth, proving a connection between the neuronal regeneration mechanisms in nematodes and vertebrate organisms.(112) However, PKC is now known to have a controversial role on neurite outgrowth, likely due to different isoforms or paralogs operating within distinct signaling contexts. Sometimes, its inhibition plays a positive role, promoting axon regeneration in a rat spinal cord injury model,(120) while in others paradigms, its activation has the same effect, as cited in the study by Samara et al. in 2010.(112)
    Al-Ali et al.(132) screened a small library containing 240 PKI compounds on embryonic rat hippocampal neurons (E18). This work had two main goals: (1) to identify PKI compounds that can promote neurite growth; and (2) to provide insight into the group of protein kinase targets that may be suitable targets for a drug discovery approach on CNS regeneration.(132) The compounds were tested at 6 different concentrations (6 nM, 32 nM, 160 nM, 800 nM, 4 μM, and 20 μM), and compounds that enhanced the neurite total length (NTL), at nontoxic concentrations, by more than 25% relative to the DMSO control were considered hits.(132)
    The screen identified some hits; among them, the four most relevant scaffolds identified were as follows: (1) the isoquinolinyl sulfonamides and the isoquinoline 5-sulfonyl analogue, ML-7 (Figure 6B). Isoquinolinyl sulfonamides are known to be ROCK inhibitors,(145) and can modulate two critical regulators of neurite growth actin-myosin turnover and dynamics.(146−148) Four of the five tested ROCK inhibitors were classified as hits. Interestingly, the more potent ROCK inhibitor, ROCK inhibitor V (IC50 = 1.5 nM), had less of an effect on promoting neurite growth than ROCK inhibitor IV (IC50 = 11.8 nM, Figure 6B), despite having comparable or higher predicted cell permeability. ML-7 (Figure 6B) was the best molecule of the study, enhancing neurite outgrowth by 3-fold compared to the control (DMSO) with an EC50 in the nanomolar range (74 nM).(132) ROCK is not known to be the target of ML-7, and the results suggest a distinct mechanism of action, which is more likely to be associated with a specific target of ML-7.(149) (2) The second identified scaffold was bisindolylmaleimides, which are known to be inhibitors of glycogen synthase kinase-3 activity, an effector of neurite growth,(138) and potent inhibitors of PKC, exhibiting differential activity toward different PKC isoforms.(145) Three of the six bisindolylmaleimides were found to be hits, binsindolylmaleimide I (Figure 6B), Gö6983 (Figure 5B), and Ro-31-8220 (Figure 6B), with binsindolylmaleimide I being the most effective.(132) (3) Another important scaffold was the anilinoquinazolines, known as an important class of ATP-competitive tyrosine kinase inhibitors.(145) Several studies have implicated protein tyrosine kinases in regulating axon growth,(139,150) and it has long been known that protein tyrosine kinase inhibitors can promote axon growth.(150) Two compounds within this group, Src Kinase Inhibitor I and Compound 56, were classified as hits (Figure 6B).(132) (4) The last highlighted scaffold was diaminopurines. Of the 15 compounds with a 2,6-diamino-purine framework, many are cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) inhibitors.(145) Four were classified as hits: Olomoucine II, Aminopurvalanol A (the most active compound, Figure 6B), Cdk Inhibitor p35, and the Roscovitine (S)-lsomer.(132) However, it was unclear whether these compounds promote neurite outgrowth by directly inhibiting CDK activity.
    To understand which signaling pathways are affected by the PKI hits, HEK293T cells treated with 12 of the PKI hits were probed by Western blotting for six different signaling pathways (ribosomal RPS6,(138) GSK3β,(151) Cofilin-1,(152) NFκ-B,(153) c-Jun,(154) and P42/44 MAPK(138)) previously associated with neurite outgrowth or inhibition.(132) As expected, the compounds positively and negatively affected the phosphorylation of various markers. They tested the neurite outgrowth effect of the compound ML-7, the best PKI hit, in a more relevant CNS in vitro model, the organotypic slice cultures (P5).(82) They observed that slices receiving ML-7 had significantly more axon growth compared to the DMSO control.(132) Their study shows the importance of PKI compounds as stimulators of neurite and axon outgrowth in vitro and prove that the knowledge of the activities of these compounds on cellular protein kinases can be used to identify suitable drug targets.(132)

    5.2.2. Promiscuous Drugs: Are They the Solution? Case 7: Machine Learning and Polypharmacology of Protein Kinase Drugs

    In 2015, Al-Ali et al.(133) continued his work with kinase proteins, but this time based on the discovery of less selective molecules. The high homology between the kinase catalytic domains of many proteins in numerous disorders (from neurology to cancer) makes the development of selective drugs against this protein’s domain extremely difficult. In other words, a drug designed to act on the kinase domain of a single protein is hardly specific and acts in many kinase domains of different proteins, making these drugs interesting candidates to act in mechanistically complex diseases or disorders. These multitarget drugs are known as promiscuous drugs and are best identified through the phenotypic screening. Multiple mechanisms and targets are related to the loss of capacity of regeneration of CNS,(2) a fact that makes the research and identification of active single target-based drugs even harder. Starting at this point, Bixby’s group performed a screen of 1606 known kinase inhibitor molecules at five concentrations (32 nM, 160 nM, 800 nM, 4 μM, and 20 μM) through a phenotypic assay with embryonic rat hippocampal neurons (E18).(133) They identified 292 hits that enhance neurite outgrowth compared to the control (DMSO); among them, 77 had %NTL ≥ 200. The chemical diversity of the hits suggests that they may act through different mechanisms, modulating different protein kinases.(133) They tested five hits (1024 combination) with the most different structures and kinase inhibition profiles and observed that three of the compounds seem to have a positive synergic effect, GW659386A, SB-750140, and GSK1511931A (Figure 6C).(133)
    They developed a support vector machine (SVM) technique relating the kinase inhibition profile with the neurite outgrowth activity.(133) Through this technique, they selected 52 kinases and tested their effect on neurite outgrowth through siRNA knockdown.(133) They observed that the method is efficient at identifying hits based on kinase inhibition and can be used to identify novel multitarget hits independent of chemical structure.(133) Many of the identified kinases are known regulators of neurite outgrowth (ROCKs, PKCs, RSKs, Cdks, MAPKs), but novel targets were also identified, including activated CDC42 kinase, PI3-kinaseδ, cGMP-dependent protein kinase G1, and cAMP-dependent protein kinase X.(133)
    Based on this, they identified two compounds with complementary effects, which act on all seven target groups.(133) Their combined effect is higher than any of the 1606 individual compounds and the 1024 combinations of the five best hit compounds. Among them, RO0480500-002 (Figure 6C) presents a strong polypharmacology profile and the ability to promote neurite outgrowth in cortical and hippocampal neurons.(133) It inhibits some kinase proteins that are known to regulate neurite outgrowth, like PKC and ROCK;(120,155,156) growth regulatory S6 kinases;(157,158) cGMP-dependent protein kinase G 1 and cAMP-dependent protein kinase X. RO0480500-002 also stimulates the growth of cortico-spinal axons in a mouse model. However, some chemical modifications are necessary to increase RO0480500-00 half-life (t1/2 < 1 min).(133,159) The SVM method are able to identify molecules with different scaffolds and similar activities; however, it is limited to the existing profile data, but is not able to identify new or nonprofiled kinases.(133)

    5.2.3. Classic is Good. Case 8: Discovery and Optimization of Sulfonamidoacetamides

    In 2016, Choi’s group screened 170,000 synthetic small molecules from commercially available libraries.(134) The compounds were tested at a 10 μM dose through a phenotypic screen with the neuronal differentiation of P19 embryonic carcinoma cells with regard to its ability to promote neurite outgrowth.(160,161) The derivatives that enhanced neurite outgrowth by more than two times compared to the control (DMSO) were selected. In total, 185 compounds (0.11% hit rate) were identified as hits and submitted to a second screen with rat primary hippocampal neurons. Compounds with a sulfonamidoacetamide scaffold were identified as the most active, especially compound 1 (Figure 6D), which enhanced neurite outgrowth by more than three times compared to the control, at concentrations between 10 and 20 μM.(134) However, due to its low water solubility and poor metabolic stability, compound 1 is not a good candidate for in vivo tests.
    Thus, the group synthesized 32 new sufonamidoacetamide derivatives based on the compound 1 scaffold.(134) Between them, compound 7p, where the ethoxy-phenyl group at section 3 is replaced by a 4-methoxy-pyridine (Figure 6D), exhibits improved neurite outgrowth (hippocampus and cerebral cortex rat E18 neurons) activity when compared to compound 1. This substitution also increases the water solubility and metabolic stability (both relative to compound 1) and can be related to the reduction in lipophilicity (Log P = 2.43) of compound 7p when compared to compound 1 (Log P = 3.76).(134) Then, compound 7p was tested for its ability to stimulate axon growth of RGCs in vitro at concentrations between 2 and 20 μM, showing good activity, especially at 10 μM. The animal model was the last step of this study. They employed the model of optic nerve injury in rats, and found that the number and length of axons beyond the lesion epicenter from animals treated with compound 7p were significantly higher when compared to those from the control animals treated with PBS. This work identified a new active scaffold to promote neurite outgrowth and axonal generation in both in vitro and in vivo models and performed an important SAR study to improve the solubility and stability of the hit compound.(134)

    5.4. When the Size Matters. Case 9: Mixture-Based Scaffold Ranking Approach

    In contrast to ancient screens, carried out with relatively small compound libraries (between 100 and 170,000 compounds), Al-Ali et al.(135) employed a mixture-based approach to screen more than 400 million compounds in 79 scaffold ranking libraries. The libraries were arranged so that each contained close structural analogues based on a single core scaffold. They performed a phenotypic screening with embryonic (E18) rat hippocampal neurons with 79 mixtures at six doses ranging from 10 μg/mL to 3.2 μg/mL.(135) The most active mixture was able to enhance neurite outgrowth by more than 2-fold compared to the control (DMSO).(135) They identified imidazolidine as the most active scaffold present in this mixture, and generated 116 subset mixtures to perform positional scanning to identify the best positions on the imidazolidine scaffold to improve activity. The subsets were tested using the same protocol as in the first step at six different concentrations ranging from 10 μg/mL to 0.003 μg/mL.(135) Based on these results, they chose three different functional groups for each position, resulting in 27 synthesized and purified compounds. Five of the 27 compounds (compounds 14, 16, 23, 25, and 26, Figure 6E) induced neurite outgrowth by at least 200% relative to the control in a nanomolar dose. This potency is comparable to, or exceeds, those for extracellular ligands. In light of these results, they speculate that their hits may be acting through an extracellular receptor.(135)

    Part II: Perspectives and Main Challenges. 6. Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As many proteins and targets are involved in the pathways to promote axonal regeneration in the CNS, the phenotypic-based screening (observing neurite outgrowth) was the most commonly used technique to identify hit molecules.(133−135) Among all of the studies performed so far, two major neurite outgrowth assays were employed: (1) measurement of the ability of drugs to help neurons overcome extrinsic factor barriers, when neurons are grown in the presence of an inhibitory environment (e.g., MAG) and the drugs;(109−111,113) and (2) measurement of the ability of drugs to stimulate intrinsic factors, when neurons are grown in the presence of the drugs and neurite outgrowth was measured.(132−135) The majority of the studies employed phenotypic screening against embryonic neurons (from rats or stem cell-derived neurons).(113,128,132,133,135) Huebner et al. allowed the embryonic neurons to acquire a more mature phenotype, closer to adult neurons, before the tests.(128) One study developed and employed a femtosecond laser microsurgery in C. elegans(112) and another used target screening.(111) Recently, Loers et al. screened a phage display peptide library (containing 109 different filamentous phages presenting 12-mer peptides on the coat protein pIII) against chondroitin-4-sulfate (C4S; a glycosaminoglycan that composes CSPGs)(162) and identified three peptides that are able to promote neurite outgrowth (in mouse cerebellar neurons and human neuroblastoma cells) by the inhibition of CSPG substrates in vitro.(162) The most popular in vivo technique with which to evaluate the effects of the in vitro hits was the optic nerve crush injury in rats, due to the ability to observe axonal regeneration through the optic nerve.(109−111,113,134)
    So far, no work using a drug design approach, computational or not, has been employed to identify hits. Even if the identification of up- and down-regulated proteins(89) after axon injury opens up the possibility to develop peptidomimetic molecules, most of the studies employed chemical database screening techniques to identify the hits. The size of screened databases varied between 100(112) and 400 million(135) (when in mixtures) molecules. Through them, many molecules and scaffolds were identified as promoters of neurite outgrowth, at nano-(110,133,135) and micromolar concentrations,(128,134) sometimes improving the ability of neurons to overcome the extrinsic factors, and sometimes stimulating the intrinsic factors. According to Al-Ali et al.,(135) the imidazolidine hit compounds that they identified acting at nanomolar concentrations have a range of potency for extracellular receptor ligands previously discovered using the same screening approach.(163) Thus, according to the potencies, it can be generally hypothesized that compounds acting at a submicromolar range are targeting an extracellular target, and compounds acting at a micromolar range are likely to interact with an intracellular target. However, Al-Ali et al. and Li et al. also identified promoters of neurite outgrowth with nanomolar potency, exerting their effects via intracellular targets,(113,133) while the L-CCB, diltiazem, identified by Huebner et al. is acting at a micromolar concentration.(128) Thus, looking at potency alone is not enough to suggest the location of the drug target.
    The highlighted scaffolds are very different, likely due to their different targets. The quinazolines were identified as inhibitors of the EGFR protein(109) and have been reported to exhibit a broad spectrum of biological activities, including anticancer, antimicrobial, antimalarial, and antihistaminic, among others (for a recent review, see Hameed et al.).(164) Triazine scaffolds were identified by Usher et al.(110) as inducers of neurite outgrowth in the presence of MAG. However, triazines are a common scaffold of herbicides, and it is necessary to understand whether the compounds are interacting with multiple targets causing the interruption of other signaling pathways.(110,165) Flavones, and especially isoflavones, were identified by the target screen using Arg 1 to overcome MAG inhibition.(111) Daidzein, the molecule identified as a hit in their work, is also known to affect various neurobiological regulatory mechanisms like behavior, cognition, growth, development, and reproduction (for a recent review, see Ahmed et al.).(166) However, in another screen by Li et al., daidzein was not identified as an inducer of neurite outgrowth in MAG presence.(113) In the same work, statins, especially simvastatin, were identified as the best molecules to promote neurite outgrowth in the presence of MAG. As statins are known to block cholesterol synthesis, they were not the most indicated treatment to induce axonal regeneration.(113) Cholesterol is essential for the formation of the myelin sheath, an important component of the neurons;(167) thus, cholesterol synthesis inhibition could lead to the formation of nonfunctional neurons. This constraint motivated the team to look for another point of inhibition on the cholesterol synthesis pathway, resulting in the disclosure of another class of molecules, the protein prenylation (PGGT and PFT) inhibitors.(113) Al-Ali et al. identified many scaffolds in their study, the most important of which were isoquinolinyl sulfonamides and the isoquinoline 5-sulfonyl analogue, bisindolylmaleimides, anilinoquinazolines, and diaminopurines. All of them are likely to act via a kinase inhibition mechanism. The sulfonamidoacetamide scaffold was highlighted by Ku et al. after the identification of compound 1 (Figure 5H) though the phenotypic screen against P19 embryonic carcinoma cells, and was confirmed on embryonic (E18) rat hippocampal neurons. So far, this work is the only to have used a hit to lead a strategy in order to identify a compound that is more suitable for in vivo studies due to the improvement of the solubility and metabolic stability of compound 1, resulting in the identification of compound 7p. Compound 7p presents a good activity in vitro and in vivo, proving the importance of a sulfonamidoacetamide scaffold as a promoter of axonal regeneration in CNS. The inhibition of Ca2+ was already known to enhance RGC survival, and induced axonal regeneration in the lesioned optic nerve.(21) In addition, the identification of diltiazem, an L-CCB molecule, by Huebner et al. was an important contribution highlighting the importance of the L-type calcium channel in axonal regeneration.(128) The identification of hits and scaffolds through screens also contributed to identify new important targets (e.g., EGFR)(109) or pathways (e.g., protein prenylation),(113) which had not been previously identified. A review of all of the most important characteristics of each screen is shown in Table 1.
    Table 1. Review of the Main Information from the Screening Studies Detailed
    articlefirst screening testsdatabase sizein vivomodelscaffold or class of moleculemechanism/targetpotency (in vitro)
    Works Concerning Screens against Extrinsic Factors
    Koprivica et al. (2005)(109)CGN (P7–9)400Optic nerve injury (mice)4-phenyl-quinazolineEGFR inhibitorsnM and μM
    Usher et al. (2010)(110)Mouse CGNs (P8)400Optic nerve injury (rats)TriazinesMicrotubules?nM
    Ma et al. (2010)(111)Immortalized hippocampal cell clones (HT22ap)2000Optic nerve injury (rats)IsoflavoneIncrease of Arg1 (cAMP-independent)μM
    Li et al. (2016)(113)Embryonic mouse stem cell-derived motor neurons (mES-MNs)50,401Optic nerve injury (rats)Statins and Protein prenylation inhibitorsProtein prenylationnM
    Huebner et al. (2019)(128)Embryonic (E18) rat cortical neurons, 21 DIV960No in vivo testAntagonists of L-type calcium channelL-type calcium channelμM
    Works Concerning Screens against Intrinsic Factors
